While President Hu tours the U.S., there are thousands of people back in China who are desperate to have a word with him.
They are part of a tradition that is hundreds of years old.
People from all over the country travel to Beijing to try to find a sympathetic ear in the government.
As NPR's Anthony Kuhn reports from Beijing, many end up frustrated and living in very poor conditions.
Down a deadend ally near the train station on Beijing's south side, people are coming in and out of an unmarked metal door.
Judging from their worn and dowdy clothes, they appear to be farmers and outoftowners.
Just inside, in a narrow, openair hallway, people are cooking lunch on a coal stove.
On either side of the hallway are several dark rooms.
In each, a lone light bulb hanging from the ceiling illuminates walls covered in newspapers.
Ragged and musty quilts sit atop a makeshift wooden platform which sleeps ten.
Another ten sleep on the floor, underneath the platform.
This Dickensian place is a hostel for people who have come from across the country in search of justice.
(Speaking foreign language)
Forty-three year old Ing Yin Shen is from a village in eastern Zhejiang (ph) Province.
She claims that her village's Communist Party Secretary kidnapped and sold her seven-year-old son.
It was an act of revenge, she said, for a business dispute between her family and the party secretary.
After 17 trips to Beijing and five years of trying to get her son back, Ing finally walked right up to the gates of power this January, with a megaphone in her hand.
(Speaking foreign language)
At 6:00 a.m. I went to the gate of Premier Wen Jiabao's home and I yelled for him.
Then I went to President Hu Jintao's home and I yelled for him too.
I believe Premier Wen now knows about my case, she says, and I'm just waiting for his response.
Ing didn't want to be yelling on the president's doorstep, it's just that she'd tried everything else.
(Speaking foreign language)
The courts wouldn't hear my case, she says, they completely ignored it.
Local media also refused to report on her case, she adds.
At any time thousands of people like Ing are in Beijing seeking an end to suffering and injustice, crime and corruption.
They travel from all over the country here by bus, train, and on foot in hope of finding a sympathetic and powerful official who will come to their rescue.
It's a tradition that dates back more than a thousand years.
In Imperial times, Chinese law allowed commoners to appeal their cases all the way to the capital if they couldn't get justice at the local level.
Today, China still has a system in place for citizens to appeal their grievances, but experts say it resolves a tiny fraction of the cases brought by petitioners.
Some experts are calling for the system to be scrapped.
Wong Li Ju (ph) from Halajian province in China's northeast and Don She Lu (ph) from central Hube province are brothers in suffering.
They stand together in the hallway washing wilted cabbage leaves.
(Speaking foreign language)
These are all scraps we picked out of the garbage at a nearby market, they say.
We can't afford to buy vegetables.
Like many petitioners, Wong has no home to return to.
His home was demolished by real estate developers who, he says, colluded with the local government.
Wu Zhiyin is a farmer from eastern Jiangsu province.
He rolls up his shirt to reveal a scar.
He says it's a knife wound inflicted by his local party secretary's son two years ago.
That's what Wu got for blowing the whistle on illegal local taxes.
Despite it all, Wu believes that the country's leadership is on his side.
(Through translator)
We farmers still have hope in Hu Jintao and Wen Jiabao, he explains, because they abolished the agriculture tax after taking office.
I want to ask you about executive pay.
Your CEO, Alan Mulally, was asked at the hearing about his $22 million compensation package and whether he'd be willing to cut his own salary.
And he said, I think I'm OK where I am.
Why is that OK when Ford is joining and asking for a taxpayer bailout?
Well, I mean, it's - first of all, you know, we are looking at it.
And we are talking to Alan about it.
I don't know if you know this, but I stopped taking any compensation myself four years ago.
Well, what about your CEO?
Well, as I say, we're talking with Alan and the comp committee.
And, you know, we are very sensitive to public opinion, and it's something that we're on top of.
There was another thing that really set people in Congress' teeth on edge, and that was the transportation issue that all three CEOs flew in for the hearing on private luxury jets.

And you will know that Congressman Gary Ackerman told them that to see them come off their jets with tin cups in their hands was ""almost like seeing a guy show up at the soup kitchen in a high hat and tuxedo."" Do you agree that that was just the wrong signal to be sending to Congress?
Yeah.
And we - yes, and we get it.
And we're taking a real look at that - at our whole plane operation.
We've sold a number of planes already, and we're taking a good hard look at all the rest of them as well.
You've all been working on your plan that you'd present to Congress in hopes of getting this bailout.
Do you think that the plan will convince them to give you the money?
I can't speak to the other companies because I don't know what their plans are.
But our plan won't change.
I mean, it's interesting, you know, we started on this several years ago.
We are bringing our very, very fuel-efficient European models to the United States.
And we're going to build them here.
And so we were already on this long before there were ever congressional hearings.
And I think that was, you know, that was the right thing to do when we decided it several years ago.
And as I say, I think it's even more the right thing to do today.
Did it surprise you that the reception in Congress was as chilly as it seemed to be?
Yeah, I guess it kind of did.
I think that although - I think our timing couldn't have been worse, just - and not our own fault.
But, you know, coming right on the heels of the big federal financial institution bailout and where a lot of the members of Congress had to go home for re-election and hear about it.
And then we show up right on the heels of that.
I think that, you know, clearly our timing wasn't great.
Well, Mr. Ford, thanks for talking with us today.
Well, thank you very much.
I really enjoyed it.
Thanks.
